earthjustice.org  (WEB - en-US)

The website of Earthjustice, a nonprofit environmental law organization that publishes news and other content in support of its advocacy work.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Earthjustice is a tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization headquartered in San Francisco. It earned more than $90 million in revenue during its last fiscal year, according to the organization’s 2016 tax filings, nearly 96 percent of which came from contributions and grants. Earthjustice.org says that 70 percent of contributed revenue comes from individuals, 25 percent comes from foundations, and 5 percent from estate gifts.

The website does not run advertisements.

Content

Earthjustice says it uses “the power of law and the strength of partnership to protect people’s health, to preserve magnificent places and wildlife, to advance clean energy, and to combat climate change” because “the earth needs a good lawyer.” It pursues litigation focused in three main areas: “the wild,” “healthy communities,” and “clean energy and a healthy climate.”

Earthjustice.com publishes blog posts, press releases, feature articles, legal documents, “action alerts” (calls for readers to respond to a particular problem), and links to relevant articles from outside news outlets. On a typical day, featured content may include an article about the environmental impact of coal ash, a blog post about state-led efforts to combat global warming, and a press release about the group’s opposition to proposed fees for demonstrations in Washington.

A prominent counter on the Earthjustice.org homepage tracks the number of lawsuits Earthjustice has filed against the Trump administration. These lawsuits are listed and described on a dedicated page.

Credibility

Earthjustice has won several important legal victories,including a landmark U.S. Supreme Court ruling that mandated the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate greenhouse gasses. According to its website, Earthjustice is involved in nearly 400 active cases. Its 2017 annual report lists more than 600 clients, which include cities, organizations, and individuals.

Charity Navigator, an independent organization that evaluates nonprofits based on their financial documents, has awarded Earthjustice its highest rating every year since 2006. Earthjustice has also received top ratings from the Better Business Bureau’s Wise Giving Alliance, GuideStar, and CharityWatch.

Although articles on Earthjustice.org are written to advance the organization’s goals, they are typically fact-based and cite credible sources, including legal documents and articles by leading news outlets. Content is labeled by its type, such as blog post and press release.

NewsGuard could not find examples of corrections on Earthjustice.org. Two emails sent to a general media inquiry address asking about the site’s corrections policy went unanswered.

Transparency

Blog posts and some feature articles on Earthjustice.org name the author, and often link to an archive of the writer’s work and a short biography. An Our Team page lists the names, titles, and biographies of all Earthjustice staff members, including senior leadership, and links to separate pages that include biographical information for the organization’s board of trustees and for a group of outside advisors. A Contact Us page lists the general phone numbers and email addresses, as well as physical addresses, of Earthjustice’s headquarters and regional offices throughout the U.S.

Earthjustice’s financial information, including its tax filings and annual reports, is available on the site. The names of individual donors who contributed to the organization are not disclosed, which is permissible by law. Earthjustice does list the foundations from which it receives support, as well as the organizations and individuals that have provided in-kind donations (support that comes in the form of goods and services.)
